newsitem.title: FRANCE: French prosecutors open new probe of Paris mayor.
newsitem.headline: French prosecutors open new probe of Paris mayor.

text.p: Prosecutors have opened a new judicial investigation into allegations that Gaullist Paris mayor Jean Tiberi and his wife illegally received cash from public funds, justice sources said on Friday.
A court annulled an earlier investigation on technical grounds last Friday.
The new probe, involving slightly modified charges, was opened by prosecutors in the southern Paris suburb of Evry, the sources said.

Tiberi, re-elected to parliament last month, had been placed under investigation earlier this year over the payment of 200,000 francs ($33,700) to his wife by the Essonne district council in exchange for a 36-page report on prospects for economic links between Essonne and French-speaking nations.
The report was largely composed of truisms copied from a book and was riddled with spelling mistakes.

Tiberi was alleged to have personally negotiated the payment for his wife with Essonne council leader Xavier Dugoin, a fellow Gaullist. An investigation targeting Dugoin was also dropped as a result of last week's court action.
The court had annulled the investigation at the request of Tiberi's lawyers.

It ruled that an investigating magistrate had used incorrect procedure in seizing the report and had improperly prepared an official account of a search of the mayor's flat, during which the report was found.
Tiberi, who succeeded President and fellow Gaullist Jacques Chirac as the French capital's mayor in 1995, is also the focus of two other inquiries.

One concerns suspected illicit funding of his Gaullist RPR party by the Paris municipal housing authority and the other involves a scandal over the letting of city-owned flats to political associates and relatives at lower than market rents.
Tiberi has denied any wrongdoing and has vowed to stay in office. ($ = 5.926 French Francs)
